---
title: A Comparison Between Multilayer Perceptrons and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
  for Multi-Task Classification in Sitting Posture Recognition
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-D5MLV3UF" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Carneros-Prado, D., Cabañero-Gómez, L., Ruiz, M. E. J., González, I., Fontecha, J., &#38; Hervás, R. (2024). A Comparison Between Multilayer Perceptrons and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks for Multi-Task Classification in Sitting Posture Recognition. <i>IEEE Access</i>, <i>12</i>, 180198–180209. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2024.3510034">https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2024.3510034</a></div> </div>

</article>
<div id="csl-bib-meta-D5MLV3UF" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-D5MLV3UF" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Carneros-Prado et al. gjennomførte ein studie som samanlikna to typar datamodellar, Kolmogorov-Arnold-nettverk (KAN) og Flerlagsperseptron (MLP), for å gjenkjenne sitteposisjonar. Målet var å bidra til å førebyggje helseproblem forårsaka av dårlege sittevanar. Ved bruk av eit datasett oppretta med MediaPipe, som trekkjer ut skjelettinformasjon, merka dei posisjonar for over- og underkropp i ulike sitte-scenario. Studien fann at KAN var meir nøyaktige (97,03% for overkropp og 92,11% for underkropp) og brukte færre ressursar enn MLP. Sjølv om MLP arbeidde raskare, viste begge modellane høg nøyaktigheit, noko som gjer dei eigna for sanntids overvaking av sitteposisjon. Denne forskinga er viktig for utvikling av system som automatisk kan vurdere og forbetre sitteposisjon, og fremje betre helse i våre stillesittande livsstilar.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-D5MLV3UF" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Gjenkjenning av sitteposisjon, Kolmogorov-Arnold-nettverk, Flerlagsperseptron, MediaPipe, Skjelettuttrekking, Ergonomisk gjenkjenning
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-D5MLV3UF" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    Prolonged incorrect sitting postures can lead to various health issues, including musculoskeletal disorders and reduced quality of life. Efficient and accurate methods for monitoring and assessing sitting postures are crucial for promoting overall well-being in our increasingly sedentary society. This study compares the performance of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) and Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) in sitting posture recognition, utilizing a multi-task classification approach to simultaneously identify upper and lower body positions. A comprehensive dataset of sitting postures was developed using MediaPipe for skeletal extraction, labeled for both body regions, and encompassing a range of common scenarios. The models were implemented and evaluated using Leave-One-Subject-Out (LOSO) cross-validation to assess generalization capability across different individuals. Results indicated that the KAN model achieved higher accuracy (97.03% for upper body and 92.11% for lower body) with fewer parameters (4,320) compared to the MLP (93.87% and 91.47% respectively, with 7,662 parameters). Although the MLP demonstrated faster inference, both models achieved accuracies exceeding 91% in LOSO validation, suggesting their potential for real-time applications. This study significantly contributes to the field of automatic posture recognition, offering insights into the applicability of KANs and MediaPipe-based pose estimation in ergonomic recognition systems and demonstrating the effectiveness of a multi-task approach for comprehensive sitting posture analysis.
  </article>
